revisions:
[{'created': '2020-04-15 22:00:08.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: additional inventory filters for tripleo-upgrade

Change-Id: I3daf77f099fd0277a9d8495932ca3e28ae7b964d
'}, {'created': '2020-04-16 11:05:32.000000000', 'message': '[upgrade] Add inventory filters to map groups to roles

tripleo-upgrade previously relied on <service_group>.children.keys to determine
which roles include a particular service.

Since I2cc721676005536b14995980f7a042991c92adcc altered the inventory
structure this will no longer work.

Create filters to generate a group to role mapping instead. Use the
tripleo_role_name var to determine the role names instead of group names.

Change-Id: I3daf77f099fd0277a9d8495932ca3e28ae7b964d
'}]
commit_message:
[upgrade] Add inventory filters to map groups to roles

tripleo-upgrade previously relied on <service_group>.children.keys to determine
which roles include a particular service.

Since I2cc721676005536b14995980f7a042991c92adcc altered the inventory
structure this will no longer work.

Create filters to generate a group to role mapping instead. Use the
tripleo_role_name var to determine the role names instead of group names.

Change-Id: I3daf77f099fd0277a9d8495932ca3e28ae7b964d

[{'account_id': 30447, 'date': '2020-02-21 01:39:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2020-02-21 08:38:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(7 comments)

Before looking into the detail, I noticed you are doing coding style changes together (single quote to double quote, wrapping lines and so on). It makes it hard to review what are actually changed. Could you make it in a separate patch if you would like to have them?'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2020-02-21 08:40:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 30447, 'date': '2020-02-23 21:54:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thanks for the feedback Akihiro Motoki. There's a lot of stuff here for me to fix."}, {'account_id': 30447, 'date': '2020-02-24 21:04:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 30447, 'date': '2020-02-25 03:33:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 30447, 'date': '2020-02-25 03:57:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

(5 comments)

I've resubmitted the patch less the code style changes and addressed most of you feedback. It's a much smaller patch now and should be simpler to review."}, {'account_id': 30447, 'date': '2020-02-26 00:14:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 30447, 'date': '2020-02-27 02:31:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 30447, 'date': '2020-02-28 02:41:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 30447, 'date': '2020-03-04 03:07:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Patch Set 6 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 30447, 'date': '2020-03-28 13:41:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Patch Set 7 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2020-04-01 09:50:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 30447, 'date': '2020-04-01 23:13:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2020-04-07 10:03:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review+2

LGTM'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2020-04-14 06:25:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

(7 comments)

I spent time to understand what is swift storage policy.
A name for a policy itself should be human readable, so I cannot understand why we need to introduce display_name.
The swift document says "Policy names exist for human readability and translation is managed in the proxy" [1].
If your deployment uses some mechanical names, it is just up to your deployment.
Looking at the code, it looks like "display_name" support introduces unnecessary complexity.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/swift/latest/overview_policies.html#containers-and-policies'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2020-04-14 13:53:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

Please ignore my comments in patch set 6. I totally forgot my draft comments in patch set 6. They were accidentally published.
Comments in patch set 9 are valid.'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2020-04-15 00:48:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

> (7 comments)
 > 
 > I spent time to understand what is swift storage policy.
 > A name for a policy itself should be human readable, so I cannot
 > understand why we need to introduce display_name.
 > The swift document says "Policy names exist for human readability
 > and translation is managed in the proxy" [1].
 > If your deployment uses some mechanical names, it is just up to
 > your deployment.
 > Looking at the code, it looks like "display_name" support
 > introduces unnecessary complexity.
 > 
 > [1] https://docs.openstack.org/swift/latest/overview_policies.html#containers-and-policies

The problem isn't that the policy names aren't human readable, it's that they aren't human understandable. Flavors in nova have a similar problem, but for them you have metadata that tells you what they do (VCPU, RAM, etc), so even then the name is potentially meaningless, but the metadata tells you, and we show that metadata in Horizon. Swift doesn't really provide you more useful information about the policies, so everything needs to be in the name.

So you have some context, let me explain what our policies are, and how we use them. 

These are our policies right now:
nz--o1--mr-r3
nz-por-1--o1--sr-r3
nz-hlz-1--o1--sr-r3
nz-wlg-2--o1--sr-r3

Their format is: <Region>--<service_tier>--<policy-type/product>

And the '--' is needed because that helps us map that policy to a product, where '--' is replaced to a '.'.
nz--o1--mr-r3
to
NZ.o1.sr-r3

Looking at those, you don't understand them. But they are human readable and technically they have all the needed info based on our other product name conventions to figure out what they mean.

We could rename them to:
nz--objectstorage-tier-1--multi-region-3-replicas
or even
multi-region-3-replicas

But that would be too long, and still doesn't look very pretty, or harder to map to the product. And for a lot of people deploying Swift I'm willing to bet they too have done human-readable, but not easily understandable policy names. Policy names are limited to only letters, digits or a dash, and are case insensitive. That limits what you can actually do in them, and there isn't an extra 'description' field to be able to describe what the policy does. That's why we chose to make the policy fit as close as possible to our standard product/service convention (e.g flavors like: "c1.c1r2" with the per region product being "NZ-POR-1.c1.c1r2").

So what we want is to have those policies represented as a 'pretty' descriptive format for Horizon, because the dashboard should focus on usability first.
"nz--o1--mr-r3" maps to "Multiple Regions, 3 Replicas"
"nz-por-1--o1--sr-r3" maps to "Single Region: nz-por-1, 3 Replicas"

This makes consuming the service MUCH easier and more understandable on the dashboard, with a tiny amount of extra complexity.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2020-04-15 09:51:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

Thanks Adrian. I understand the situation. I would like to know the original source (swift document or source code) for future maintenance (so that future contributors can understand it).'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2020-04-15 09:53:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

-1 is kept till I get the original source of the policy name requirements and also get a reply to a question on the value of the proposed css.'}, {'account_id': 30447, 'date': '2020-04-15 09:58:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(1 comment)

Akihiro, is this what you need?

https://docs.openstack.org/swift/latest/overview_policies.html#defining-a-policy

>Each policy section contains the following options:
>    name = <policy_name> (required)
>            The primary name of the policy.
>            Policy names are case insensitive.
>            Policy names must contain only letters, digits or a dash.
>            Policy names must be unique.
>            Policy names can be changed.
>            The name Policy-0 can only be used for the policy with index 0.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2020-04-15 10:23:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

What I would like to know is the source of "Their format is: <Region>--<service_tier>--<policy-type/product>". Your comment says it is required by swift, so I would like to confirm it.'}, {'account_id': 30447, 'date': '2020-04-15 10:37:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

>Their format is: <Region>--<service_tier>--<policy-type/product>

That is for your understanding of what our storage policy names represent, I.e how the policy names are formed.

>nz--o1--mr-r3
>nz-por-1--o1--sr-r3
>nz-hlz-1--o1--sr-r3
>nz-wlg-2--o1--sr-r3

As Adrian stated:

>We could rename them to:
>nz--objectstorage-tier-1--multi-region-3-replicas
>or even
>multi-region-3-replicas
>
>But that would be too long, and still doesn't look very pretty

The other constraint that we have is hat we are running a public cloud and need to be able to map telemetry based on on the policy names to 'products' that we can bill for which is what Adrian is talking about below.

> And the '--' is needed because that helps us map that policy to a > product, where '--' is replaced to a '.'
> nz--o1--mr-r3
> to
> NZ.o1.sr-r3

Regardless of how verbose we make the policy names though, the constraints on policy names described by in the docs[1] impede understandably and user experience and we would like to add the ability to optionally alter how policy names are displayed on the dashboard purely in a cosmetic capacity.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/swift/latest/overview_policies.html#defining-a-policy"}, {'account_id': 30447, 'date': '2020-04-15 12:13:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(1 comment)

>question: How is this value chosen? Does it work for various screen sizes? why 58? why not 60 for example?

See below'}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2020-04-15 15:15:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2020-04-15 15:20:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2020-04-15 18:18:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

While I read through your comments,
I still don't think I fully understand the need for display_name.
I try to raise my questions and decision points one by one.

* I requested the source (document or code) from the swift team and you referred to [1].
  According to [1], the constraints for 'name' is not so strict and you can define
  any human-readable names.

* You mentioned the format of 'name' is "<Region>--<service_tier>--<policy-type/product>",
  but according to [1] there is no such requirements.
  I still do not understand why such format is required.

* You also mentioned "we are running a public cloud and need to be able to map telemetry
  based on on the policy names to 'products' that we can bill for which is what Adrian is talking about below".
  Is it a requirement specific to your deployment?
  If so, it looks like you are trying to address other problems by adding an option to horizon.

* Even if it is deployment-specific, when there is a reasonable background that it is unavoidable,
  it looks okay to add such option in horizon.

I am not necessarily against to add the setting, but we need to understand the need
for the option correctly before accepting it.
You explained an example but it does not explain WHY you need to use such complexity
which is not required by the swift (according to the swift documentation).
The main confusion to me is that you don't explain why and just try to explain what is needed.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/swift/latest/overview_policies.html#defining-a-policy'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2020-04-15 23:40:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

@amotiki

The swift policy name is not at all strict beyond the alphanumeric or dashes, the issue is that makes for ugly human readable names descriptive names. Policies can represent a replication type or number, a region, etc. There are too many things that describe a policy for it to fit nicely into a name in a descriptive fashion. Swift provides no metadata for holding that info on the policy, so the name has to describe everything, which is ugly and long if made truly human readable.

We opted for condensed information in a format that is descriptive if you understand our naming convention, but isn't directly clear, that was our format in the style of:
"<Region>--<service_tier>--<policy-type/product>" eg "nz-por-1--o1--sr-r3"
Which has nothing to do with Swift, and simply a naming convention we chose because it made the most sense. Other clouds will probably also do something similar.

The need to also map the policy to a product was important, so our policy looks a little weird, but because most people copy/paste it, it doesn't matter. That's why we didn't do:
single-region--nz-por-1--3-replicas
single-region--nz-por-1--erasure-coded
etc

For Horizon we wanted a nice and clear truly human readable (no dashes etc) display name for the policy, so that people JUST using the dashboard can easily understand it without understanding our product naming (which they'd have to look at our price list to understand). We argued that the small amount of code needed to do that mapping/config was tiny, and well worth the usability added, while being an entirely optional feature clouds using more descriptive human readable policy names could ignore.'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2020-04-15 23:46:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

> The need to also map the policy to a product was important, so our
 > policy looks a little weird, but because most people copy/paste it,
 > it doesn't matter. That's why we didn't do:
 > single-region--nz-por-1--3-replicas
 > single-region--nz-por-1--erasure-coded
 > etc

Actually, if I was to unpack our current naming convention the fully descriptive name would actually be:
nz-por-1--object-storage-tier-1--single-region-3-replicas

Which is way to long, but the same info is conveyed via 'nz-por-1--o1--sr-r3' just not as obviously."}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2020-04-16 00:07:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

Thanks for the detail explanation and your patience. I now understand the need from the operator side. I am okay with introducing display_name.
Once the scss issue is addressed, we can move it forward.'}, {'account_id': 30447, 'date': '2020-04-16 10:17:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 30447, 'date': '2020-04-16 10:21:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

Amotaki, magic number was an easy fix - replaced the entire CSS rule just with just the "col-lg-offset-7" class in the markup.

Sorry it took a while - I went down a rabit hole of trying to improve all of the layout in the container information box but I will submit additional layout changes as a separate patch.

This patch keeps the styling of the new label and value 100% consistent with existing styling.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2020-04-17 07:33:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2020-04-17 08:37:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Add support for multiple swift storage policies

+ Adds endpoint for listing available policies
+ Support to select a storage policy for new containers
+ Display container storage polcy on dashboard.

Change-Id: I588452fd5d6417859f5dd19ccedcb18f420ab646

subject: [k8s] Expose traefik prometheus metrics
messages:
[{'account_id': 29425, 'date': '2019-12-03 10:13:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 29425, 'date': '2019-12-03 10:14:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

Still needs validation/testing'}, {'account_id': 20498, 'date': '2020-03-31 11:52:48.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

The magnum team is cleaning up the backlog of changes older than 30 days. Feel to restore your patch.'}, {'account_id': 29425, 'date': '2020-03-31 12:24:52.000000000', 'content': 'Restored

Do not abandon this'}, {'account_id': 29425, 'date': '2020-04-03 03:42:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Published edit on patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 29425, 'date': '2020-04-03 03:57:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)

I want to raise some security concerns.

We currently use traefik with a HostPort implementation, this means 
that all this ports will be open on the nodes. 

From a point of view of user app, leaking data outside is not 'safe'. 
If the nodes where the ports are open do not have an extra external 
firewall the nefarious user can get information on data from other 
user number of connections, number of endpoints etc.

All this by accessing node:8080 and (now) node:8082

In my opinion, i don't think that the metrics supplied by traefik in 
v1 are word exposing this endpoint. Never the less, the same happens 
to the nginx ingress as it also works under HorstPort but supplies 
much more information. Do i make sense?

Clearly, using the HostPort is not advised and not production 
recommended by the motives i presented above. I didn't contemplated
this aspect before... 

How we should proceed? Add the patch either way to maintain consensus,
or drop all statistics from the ingress proxy (nginx/traefik) all
together? This includes also to stop making the port 8080 on traefik
and probably there is something similar used by nginx."}, {'account_id': 29425, 'date': '2020-04-03 04:16:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 29425, 'date': '2020-04-03 04:19:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Published edit on patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 20498, 'date': '2020-04-03 07:20:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> (2 comments)
 > 
 > I want to raise some security concerns.
 > 
 > We currently use traefik with a HostPort implementation, this means
 > that all this ports will be open on the nodes.
 > 
 > From a point of view of user app, leaking data outside is not
 > 'safe'.
 > If the nodes where the ports are open do not have an extra external
 > firewall the nefarious user can get information on data from other
 > user number of connections, number of endpoints etc.
 > 
 > All this by accessing node:8080 and (now) node:8082
 > 
 > In my opinion, i don't think that the metrics supplied by traefik
 > in
 > v1 are word exposing this endpoint. Never the less, the same
 > happens
 > to the nginx ingress as it also works under HorstPort but supplies
 > much more information. Do i make sense?
 > 
 > Clearly, using the HostPort is not advised and not production
 > recommended by the motives i presented above. I didn't contemplated
 > this aspect before...
 > 
 > How we should proceed? Add the patch either way to maintain
 > consensus,
 > or drop all statistics from the ingress proxy (nginx/traefik) all
 > together? This includes also to stop making the port 8080 on
 > traefik
 > and probably there is something similar used by nginx.

1. These concerns shold be addressed in another patch.

2. hostPort is safe.

3. hostNetwork not so much."}, {'account_id': 20498, 'date': '2020-04-03 07:21:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2020-04-03 07:36:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 29425, 'date': '2020-04-03 08:44:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Published edit on patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2020-04-03 09:10:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Where can I see the collected metrics?'}, {'account_id': 29425, 'date': '2020-04-03 09:19:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Metrics are being exposed, not collected.

I moved the collection part to the helm chart as the service monitor depends on the monitoring.k8s.io/v1 CRDs that are installed after, thus making the kubectl --apply fail.

For now you can do 
kubectl -n kube-system port-forward service/ingress-traefik 9100
curl localhost:9100/metrics'}, {'account_id': 29425, 'date': '2020-04-03 10:07:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

I will add all the changes to the prometheus-operator chart at the same time'}, {'account_id': 20498, 'date': '2020-04-03 10:08:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> > (2 comments)
 > >
 > > I want to raise some security concerns.
 > >
 > > We currently use traefik with a HostPort implementation, this
 > means
 > > that all this ports will be open on the nodes.
 > >
 > > From a point of view of user app, leaking data outside is not
 > > 'safe'.
 > > If the nodes where the ports are open do not have an extra
 > external
 > > firewall the nefarious user can get information on data from
 > other
 > > user number of connections, number of endpoints etc.
 > >
 > > All this by accessing node:8080 and (now) node:8082
 > >
 > > In my opinion, i don't think that the metrics supplied by traefik
 > > in
 > > v1 are word exposing this endpoint. Never the less, the same
 > > happens
 > > to the nginx ingress as it also works under HorstPort but
 > supplies
 > > much more information. Do i make sense?
 > >
 > > Clearly, using the HostPort is not advised and not production
 > > recommended by the motives i presented above. I didn't
 > contemplated
 > > this aspect before...
 > >
 > > How we should proceed? Add the patch either way to maintain
 > > consensus,
 > > or drop all statistics from the ingress proxy (nginx/traefik) all
 > > together? This includes also to stop making the port 8080 on
 > > traefik
 > > and probably there is something similar used by nginx.
 > 
 > 1. These concerns shold be addressed in another patch.

I think we can use this change to configure the metrics port for traefik.
For refactoring how traefik is reached from the outside (hostNetwork vs hostPort vs something else) we can do it in another patch. Smallest change possible is good and helps reviews. We should address one thing at a time.
If you are concerned about security let's merge another patch for removing hostNetwork.

 > 
 > 2. hostPort is safe.

* hostNetwork means there is not network namespace. All ports used by traefik are open on the node.

* On the other hand, with hostPort the traefik pod/process has a network namespace and only ports 80/433 or any other hostPort is open to the host. 

This means, traefik listens to admin (8080), metrics (9100) and 80/443 for services.

* hostNetwork: all ports are reachable from the outside (if the security group/ firewall allows it) and other pods can't use any of these port on the host (in their namespace they can).

* hostPort: only 80/443 will be open in the host which is what we want in reality. We want to reach a k8s service in the cluster using ports 80/443. admin and metrics will be closed from the host. Only via an ingress will be open to the outside or within the overlay.

 > 
 > 3. hostNetwork not so much."}, {'account_id': 20498, 'date': '2020-04-03 10:15:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> I will add all the changes to the prometheus-operator chart at the
 > same time

+1'}, {'account_id': 20498, 'date': '2020-04-03 10:29:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2020-04-15 09:26:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

subject: Remove nodeSelector for flannel DaemonSet
messages: [{'account_id': 22997, 'date': '2020-04-17 03:31:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 20498, 'date': '2020-04-17 07:44:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2020-04-17 08:46:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-04-17 03:31:42.000000000', 'message': "Remove nodeSelector for flannel DaemonSet

According to upstream kube-flannel.yml PR[1], node-selector introduced
is because flannel image doesn't support multiarch manifestes. Which
means that it can't specify flannel:version-arch images in the same
daemonset for every arch platform. To make every arch platform can
deploy flannel upstream add one daemonset with nodeSelector per arch.

But in magnum flannel image tag is configurable via label, thus every
arch platform can use one daemonset to deploy by specify corresponding
flannel image tag. So nodeSelector is unnecessary here.

[1]: https://github.com/coreos/flannel/pull/989

Change-Id: I97e78e8d77973e03eeff598b212287945ca00190
Task: 39453
Story: 2007026
"}]
commit_message:
Remove nodeSelector for flannel DaemonSet

According to upstream kube-flannel.yml PR[1], node-selector introduced
is because flannel image doesn't support multiarch manifestes. Which
means that it can't specify flannel:version-arch images in the same
daemonset for every arch platform. To make every arch platform can
deploy flannel upstream add one daemonset with nodeSelector per arch.

But in magnum flannel image tag is configurable via label, thus every
arch platform can use one daemonset to deploy by specify corresponding
flannel image tag. So nodeSelector is unnecessary here.

[1]: https://github.com/coreos/flannel/pull/989

Change-Id: I97e78e8d77973e03eeff598b212287945ca00190
Task: 39453
Story: 2007026

commit_message:
Exclude rabbitmq-3.7.24 container image

This image has been added to kolla on the stable/train branch to help
with the CentOS 7 to 8 migration for Kolla Ansible. It is not applicable
to Tripleo, and fails to build due to lacking rabbitmq-3.7.24 package.
Exclude it.

Change-Id: I8a917b786604190dff3c89eb81775b0ffaa42a96

commit_message:
Release reservation when stoping the ironic-conductor service

If a conductor hostname is changed while reservations are
issued to a conductor with one hostname, such as 'hostname'
and then the process is restarted with 'new_hostname', then the
queries would not match the node and effectively the nodes
would become inaccessible until the reservation is cleared.

This patch clears the reservation when stoping the
ironic-conductor service to avoid the nodes becoming inaccessible.

Ref to: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/711765/

Change-Id: Id31cd30564ff26df0bbe4976ffe3f268b0dd3d7b

commit_message:
A boot partition on a GPT disk should be considered an EFI partition

DIB builds instance images with EFI partitions that only have the boot
flag, but not esp. According to parted documentation, boot is an alias
for esp on GPT, so accept it as well.

To avoid complexities when parsing parted output, the implementation
is switched to existing utils and ironic-lib functions.

Conflicts:
	ironic_python_agent/tests/unit/test_utils.py
	ironic_python_agent/utils.py

Change-Id: I5f57535e5a89528c38d0879177b59db6c0f5c06e
Story: #2007455
Task: #39423
(cherry picked from commit ff49b04e28b74d89a5fa6334411c56628f502bee)

commit_message:
Split Tempest tests between ipmi and redfish

- Renamed the classes from the ironic_standalone scenario
- Added logic to choose redfish as driver when possible

Change-Id: If81a39dd8bee657bba8c5cee0fead900c6e8f56c
